maml:description.maml:para: Adds a multicast scope on the DHCP server.
The Add-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet adds a multicast scope on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server.
Specifies a name for the multicast scope.
Specifies the start address of the range of IP addresses for the scope.
Specifies the end address of the range for the scope.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies a description of the multicast scope. The default value is null.
Specifies the expiry time of the multicast scope. The default value is infinite.
Specifies the duration of the IP address lease. The default value 30 days.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the state of the scope. The acceptable values for this parameter are: -- Active -- Inactive
The default value is Active.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the number of routers through which multicast traffic passes. The default value is 32.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies a description of the multicast scope. The default value is null.
Specifies the end address of the range for the scope.
Specifies the expiry time of the multicast scope. The default value is infinite.
Specifies the duration of the IP address lease. The default value 30 days.
Specifies a name for the multicast scope.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the start address of the range of IP addresses for the scope.
Specifies the state of the scope. The acceptable values for this parameter are: -- Active -- Inactive
The default value is Active.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the number of routers through which multicast traffic passes. The default value is 32.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add an inactive multicast scope

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an inactive multicast scope named Multicast_AudioConference on the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com. The command specifies the lease duration of 20 days for allocating addresses to participants of audio conferences. You can allocate a single multicast address to multiple clients. The command specifies that the traffic passes through 20 routers.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Add an active multicast scope

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates an active multicast scope named Multicast_AudioConference on the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com. You can use the multicast scope on the DHCP server service for allocating addresses to participants of video conferences. You can allocate a single multicast address to multiple clients. The traffic passes through 32 routers, and the lease duration is 30 days.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets multicast scope objects.

The Get-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet gets one or more multicast scope objects. If you do not specify the Name parameter, the cmdlet gets all multicast scopes on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get multicast scopes by using a name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the multicast scopes named Multicast_AudioConference and Multicast_VideoConference on the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.
This command gets all of the multicast scopes on the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes multicast scopes.

The Remove-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet removes the specified multicast scopes from the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server. When you remove a multicast scope, the DHCP server cannot assign the range of IP addresses to DHCP clients.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet removes the scope regardless if there are active leases in the scope.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
If you specify this parameter, the cmdlet removes the scope regardless if there are active leases in the scope.
Specifies an array of names of multicast scopes.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a multicast scope by using a name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the multicast scope named Multicast_VideoConference from the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Remove a multicast scope without a confirmation

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the multicast scope named Multicast_AudioConference from the DHCP server named DhcpServer01.Contoso.com. The cmdlet does not prompt the user for confirmation, regardless if the scopes are active or contain active client leases.

This command removes all of the disabled multicast scopes on the DHCP Server service. The Get-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet returns the multicast scope objects and passes the objects to the Where-Object cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. For more information, type Get-Help Where-Object.

The Where-Object cmdlet filters the multicast scope objects for inactive multicast scopes, and passes the objects to the Remove-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet by using the pipeline operator. The Remove-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet removes the inactive scopes.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the properties of a multicast scope.
The Set-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope cmdlet modifies the properties of a multicast scope on the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server.
Specifies the name of a multicast scope.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies a description for the scope. The default value is null.
Specifies the end address of the range for the scope.
Specifies the expiry time of the multicast scope. The default value is infinite.
Specifies the duration of the IP address lease. The default value 30 days.
Specifies a new name for the multicast scope.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the start address of the range of IP addresses for the scope.

Specifies the state of the scope. Only an active scope responds to client requests. An inactive scope exists on the server but is dormant and not functional. It does not respond. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Active -- Inactive
The default value is Active.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the number of routers through which multicast traffic can pass. The default value is 32.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name or IP address of the target computer that runs the DHCP Server service.
Specifies a description for the scope. The default value is null.
Specifies the end address of the range for the scope.
Specifies the expiry time of the multicast scope. The default value is infinite.
Specifies the duration of the IP address lease. The default value 30 days.
Specifies the name of a multicast scope.
Specifies a new name for the multicast scope.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the start address of the range of IP addresses for the scope.

Specifies the state of the scope. Only an active scope responds to client requests. An inactive scope exists on the server but is dormant and not functional. It does not respond. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- Active -- Inactive
The default value is Active.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the number of routers through which multicast traffic can pass. The default value is 32.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Modify the properties of a multicast scope
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-DhcpServerv4MulticastScope Name "Multicast_VideoConference" -ComputerName "DhcpServer01.Contoso.com" -ExpiryTime "1/1/2014 0:01 AM" -LeaseDuration 40 -NewName "Multicast_VideoConferenceBuilding1" -State Active

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command activates the multicast scope named Multicast_VideoConference and renames it Multicast_VideoConferenceBuilding1. The command sets the lease duration to 40 days and sets the expiry time of the multicast scope.
